steps.title: Clean and dry 2 inches (5 cm) of skin around the wound.
steps.content: Clean and dry 2 inches (5 cm) of skin around the wound. Remove any blood or dirt with rubbing alcohol or a cleanser like Phisoderm. Put the cleanser on a clean cloth and swab it across the area around the wound.

steps.title: Dry the skin completely.
steps.content: Dry the skin completely. If your skin has any moisture on it, the adhesive might not work properly. Pat the area dry with a dry, clean towel or cloth.

steps.title: Apply a tincture to increase adhesion.
steps.content: Apply a tincture to increase adhesion. A Benzoin tincture can help increase the adhesion between your skin and the Steri strip. Apply some tincture to a cotton swab and swab the area around the wound. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Visit your doctor if your wound is deep or very dirty.
steps.content: Visit your doctor if your wound is deep or very dirty. It's important that your wound is completely clean before you cover it with Steri strips. Otherwise, you may develop an infection under the Steri strips that can continue to worsen. See your doctor if your wound is deep or hard to clean so that it will heal correctly.

steps.title: Take the strips off the card.
steps.content: Take the strips off the card. Pull each strip up off the card by placing your index finger under the end and pulling up. [2] X Research source You can pull them off one at a time or three at once by using your index, middle, and ring fingers under the edges of three strips.

steps.title: Hold the skin on either side of the wound closed.
steps.content: Hold the skin on either side of the wound closed. Place the index finger of your hand that's not holding the Steri strips on one side of the wound. Then place the thumb of the same hand on the other side of the wound and press together.

steps.title: Start at the middle of the wound.
steps.content: Start at the middle of the wound. Applying the first strip in the middle of the wound ensures that the wound closes evenly. Then apply the rest of the strips out from the original one in the middle. It doesn’t matter if you move to the right or left (or top or bottom) first.

steps.title: Press the strips down.
steps.content: Press the strips down. While holding the wound closed, place one end of the strip above the wound. Press down as you lay the strip over the wound and secure the other end under the wound. There should be an even amount of strip above and below the wound. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Place successive strips parallel to each other.
steps.content: Place successive strips parallel to each other. How many strips you need depends on the size of the wound. There should be an 1/8th of an inch (1/3rd of a cm) between each strip and they should all be applied the same way. Apply enough strips so that the wound is closed all the way across.

steps.title: Place strips parallel to the wound across the edges of the original strips.
steps.content: Place strips parallel to the wound across the edges of the original strips. The strips that are placed parallel to the wound prevent the ends of the original strips from lifting. This ensures that your wound has time to heal before the strips start to come up. Place the strips ½ inch (1 cm) from the original strip ends.

steps.title: Keep the strips on for 3 to 5 days for head wounds.
steps.content: Keep the strips on for 3 to 5 days for head wounds. Most head wounds heal more quickly than other areas of the body. Check the strips every day to make sure the ends aren’t coming up. If they are, trim them with scissors and apply another strip parallel to the wound. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Keep the strips on for 10 to 14 days for cuts over joints.
steps.content: Keep the strips on for 10 to 14 days for cuts over joints. Wounds over joints are the most likely to heal slowly because the movement of joints continually opens the wound. Leave the strips on for 10 to 14 days. [5] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Leave the strips on for 5 to 10 days for other wounds.
steps.content: Leave the strips on for 5 to 10 days for other wounds. If your wound is not on your head or over a joint, leave the strips on for 5 to 10 days. As your wound heals, it will turn a light pink color. [6] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Check for that color before you remove the strips. If you notice that your skin is red or painful, it may be infected. Remove the Steri strips to check for an infection. If you think your wound is infected, visit your doctor to make sure you get proper treatment so your wound can heal. The strips should fall off naturally after about 14 days. [7] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Keep the wound dry until the strips are removed.
steps.content: Keep the wound dry until the strips are removed. If you get the strips wet at all, they can come off. Keep the wound dry for the period the strips should stay on. [8] X Research source You can shower as long as you can keep the wound out of the water. If you can’t keep the wound out of the water, you’ll need to take sponge baths until the wound heals.

steps.title: Remove the strips by moistening them with warm water.
steps.content: Remove the strips by moistening them with warm water. By the end of the period your strips should be on, they’ll probably be easy to gently peel off. If they resist coming over, dip a cloth in warm water and hold it over the strips for 5 to 10 minutes. Once you remove the cloth, the strips should pull off. If they don’t, moisten them again. [9] X Research source
